content: The Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2004 is also known as TITLE I. It includes the retention of the task force as stated in SEC. 102. Section 603 of the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act of 1998 is amended by removing subsection (e). The Task Force is required to consult with various stakeholders in developing assessments, reports, and plans. Additionally, a report to Congress on Harmful Algal Bloom Impacts must be submitted within 12 months of the enactment of the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2004. The President, in consultation with stakeholders, will develop a report for Congress on measures to protect environmental and public health from harmful algal blooms. The report will review techniques for predicting the onset and impacts of harmful algal blooms. The President will develop a report for Congress on measures to protect environmental and public health from harmful algal blooms, including innovative research methods and incentive-based partnership approaches. A summary of the proposed plan will be published for public comment before submission to Congress. Federal assistance will be provided by the Secretary of Commerce in coordination with the Task Force. The Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with the Task Force, will provide Federal cooperation and assistance to coastal States, Indian tribes, and local governments for scientific assessments of hypoxia and harmful algal blooms as requested. The Secretary will ensure diverse assessments on hypoxia and harmful algal blooms, establish a review procedure, and communicate findings to relevant authorities and the public. Local and regional assessments will focus on causes, consequences, costs, and prevention methods. The Task Force will conduct a scientific assessment of harmful algal blooms in freshwater areas like the Great Lakes, focusing on causes, consequences, and prevention methods. This assessment will include a research plan to coordinate Federal efforts in understanding freshwater harmful algal blooms. The Task Force will examine the causes, economic costs, and ecological consequences of harmful algal blooms in freshwater areas. They will establish priorities for a research program to better understand these blooms and improve coordination among Federal agencies. Additionally, the Task Force will conduct scientific assessments of hypoxia every 5 years. The Task Force will conduct scientific assessments of hypoxia in US coastal waters every 5 years, examining causes, consequences, and costs. They will evaluate progress in Federal research programs and recommend actions to address gaps in data. The Task Force will conduct scientific assessments of harmful algal blooms in US coastal waters every 5 years, examining causes, consequences, and ecological impacts. The assessments will include marine and freshwater harmful algal blooms, with the first assessment focusing solely on marine blooms. The Task Force will assess harmful algal blooms every 5 years, focusing on causes, consequences, and impacts. They will also evaluate Federal research programs and aim to improve coordination among agencies. The Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2004 requires the Task Force to develop a national research program to address harmful algal blooms' impacts on coastal ecosystems, public health, and the economy. The plan includes establishing priorities for research, improving coordination among federal agencies, and promoting diverse participation. The Secretary of Commerce, along with other federal agencies, will establish a research program to address harmful algal blooms' impacts. The program will prioritize diverse participation, including Historically Black Colleges and Universities and institutions serving underrepresented populations. The Secretary will ensure that program results are communicated to state, tribal, and local governments, as well as the general public. SEC. 105. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 605 of the Act is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, with specific allocations for various programs. The Act is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, with specific allocations for various programs, including $1,500,000 for each of fiscal years 2005 through 2008 to carry out section 603(e). "TITLE II--MISCELLANEOUS" - The Act is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, with specific allocations for various programs. The Secretary of Commerce may provide University of Miami with NOAA real property on Virginia Key, Florida for a Marine Life Science Center. The property can be used for environmental research, fisheries management, and educational activities. The University of Miami may use NOAA real property on Virginia Key for a Marine Life Science Center, subject to an agreement with the Secretary of Commerce outlining conditions for non-Federal use, joint occupancy with Federal agencies, and preservation of existing NOAA programs and services. The University of Miami can use NOAA property on Virginia Key for a Marine Life Science Center, with conditions outlined in an agreement with the Secretary of Commerce. The availability of the property for future Federal buildings ends if the University uses it for other purposes or violates the agreement. The Secretary can enter agreements to occupy facilities built by the University on the property and participate in collaborative research. This section does not involve the conveyance of title. The Secretary of Commerce will convey the NOAA vessel WHITING to the Government of Mexico for hydrographic surveying purposes in the Gulf of Mexico and Pacific Ocean, enhancing coordination between the two countries. No conveyance of title is involved in this transfer. The Government of the United States will not be responsible for the maintenance or operation of the vessel WHITING after it is delivered to the Government of Mexico. The Secretary aims to complete the conveyance as soon as possible after the enactment of the Act, with the vessel being delivered at no extra cost to the United States in Norfolk, Virginia.
